verses.text: “We arrived at the place where you’ve sent us,” they reported, “and it certainly does flow with milk and honey. Furthermore, this is its fruit,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: except that the people who have settled in the land are strong, and their cities are greatly fortified. We also saw the descendants of Anak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amalek lives throughout the Negev, while the Hittites, Jebusites, and Amorites live in the hill country. The Canaanites live by the sea and on the bank of the Jordan.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Caleb silenced the people on Moses’ behalf and responded, “Let’s go up and take control, because we can definitely conquer it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We can’t attack those people,” the men who were with him said, “because they’re too strong compared to us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they put out this false report to the Israelis about the land that they had explored: “The land that we’ve explored is one that devours its inhabitants. All the people whom we observed were giants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We also saw the Nephilim, the descendants of Anak. Compared to the Nephilim, as we see things, we’re like grasshoppers, and that’s their opinion of us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this, the entire assembly complained, started to shout, and cried through the rest of that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Israelis complained against Moses and Aaron. Then the entire assembly responded, “We wish that we had died in Egypt or in this wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What’s the point in the Lord bringing us to this land? To die by the sword so our wives and children would become war victims? Wouldn’t it be better for us to return to Egypt?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they told each other, “Let’s assign a leader and go back to Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron fell on their faces in front of the entire assembly of the congregation of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nun’s son Joshua and Jephunneh’s son Caleb, who had accompanied the others who also had explored the land, tore their clothes
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and attempted to reason with the entire congregation of Israel. They told them, “The land that we went through and explored is very, very good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the Lord is pleased with us, he’ll bring us into this land and give it to us. It flows with milk and honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, don’t rebel against the Lord or be afraid of the people who live in the land, because we’ll gobble them right up. Their defenses will collapse, because the Lord is with us. You are not to be afraid of them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the entire congregation was talking about stoning them to death.
Suddenly, the glory of the Lord appeared at the Tent of Meeting to all of the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How long will this people keep on spurning me and refusing to trust me, despite all the miracles that I’ve done among them?” the Lord asked Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That’s why I’m going to attack them with pestilence and disinherit them. Instead, I’ll make you a great nation—even mightier than they are!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses responded to the Lord, “When Egypt hears that you’ve brought this people out from among them with a mighty demonstration of power,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they’ll also proclaim to the inhabitants of this land that they’ve heard you’re among this people, Lord, whom they’ve seen face to face, since your cloud stands guard over them. You’ve guided them with a pillar of cloud by day and with a pillar of fire by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you slaughter this people all at the same time, then the nations who heard about your fame will say,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘The Lord slaughtered this people in the wilderness because he wasn’t able to bring them to the land that he promised them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, let the power of the Lord be magnified, just as you promised when you said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘The Lord is slow to anger and abundant in faithful love, forgiving iniquity and transgression, but he won’t acquit the guilty. He recalls the iniquity of fathers to the third and fourth generation.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Forgive, please, the iniquity of this people, according to your great, faithful love, in the same way that you’ve carried this people from Egypt to this place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord responded, “I’ve forgiven them based on what you’ve said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But just as I live, and just as the whole earth will be filled with the Lord’s glory,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: none of those men who saw my glory and watched my miracles that I did in Egypt and in the wilderness—even though they’ve tested me these ten times and never listened to my voice—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: will ever see the land that I promised to their ancestors. Those who spurned me won’t see it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as to my servant Caleb, because a different spirit is within him and he has remained true to me, I’m going to bring him into the land that he explored, and his descendants are to inherit it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Amalekite and the Canaanite live in the valley. Tomorrow, turn and then travel to the wilderness in the direction of the Reed Sea.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How long will this wicked assembly keep complaining about me? I’ve heard the complaints of the Israelis that they’ve been murmuring against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So tell them that as long as I live—consider this to be an oracle from the Lord—as certainly as you’ve spoken right into my ears, that’s how I’m going to treat you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your corpses will fall in this wilderness—every single one of you who has been counted among you, according to your number from 20 years and above, who complained against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will certainly never enter the land about which I made an oath with my uplifted hand to settle you in it, except for Jephunneh’s son Caleb and Nun’s son Joshua.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I’ll bring your little ones—the ones whom you claimed would become war victims—into the land so that they’ll know by experience the land that you’ve rejected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now as for you, your corpses will fall in this wilderness
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and your children will wander throughout the wilderness for 40 years. They’ll bear the consequences of your idolatries until your bodies are entirely consumed in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as you explored the land for 40 days, you’ll bear the consequences of your iniquities for 40 years—one year for each day—as you experience my hostility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Lord, have spoken. I will indeed do this to this evil congregation, who gathered together against me. They’ll be eliminated in this wilderness and will surely die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the men whom Moses sent out to explore the land, who returned and made the whole congregation complain against him by bringing an evil report concerning the land,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and who produced an evil report about the land, died of pestilence in the Lord’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Nun’s son Joshua and Jephunneh’s son Caleb, who had explored the land, remained alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses had told all of this to the Israelis, the people deeply mourned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they got up early the next morning and traveled to the top of the mountain, telling themselves, “Look, we’re here and we’re going to go up to the place that the Lord had spoken about, even though we’ve sinned.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses asked them, “Why do you continue to sin against what the Lord said? Don’t you know that you can never succeed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t go up, since you know that the Lord is no longer with you. You’ll be attacked right in front of your own enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amalekites and Canaanites are there waiting for you. You’ll die violently, since you’ve turned your back and have stopped following the Lord. The Lord won’t be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they presumed to go up to the top of the mountain, even though the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord and Moses didn’t leave the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Amalekites came down, accompanied by some Canaanites who lived in the mountains. They attacked and defeated them even while the Israelis were retreating to Hormah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the Lord instructed Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the Israelis that
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when you enter the land where you’ll be living that I’m about to give you, you are to make an offering by fire to the Lord, either a burnt offering, a sacrificial offering to fulfill a vow, or a voluntary offering at the appointed time, to make a pleasing aroma to the Lord either from your cattle or from your flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The offeror is to bring the oblation to the Lord, containing one tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a grain offering, mixed with one fourth of a hin of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also prepare one fourth of a hin of wine for a drink offering or for the sacrifice of each lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “For a ram, prepare a grain offering consisting of two tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with one third of a hin of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now as for your drink offering, offer one third of a hin of wine as a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you prepare a bull as a burnt offering, or as a sacrifice to fulfill a vow, or for peace offerings to the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then the bullock is to be presented accompanied by a meal offering of three tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with half a hin of oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for drink offerings, offer half a hin of wine, for an offering made by fire is a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do this for each bullock, ram, male lamb, or goat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Depending on the number of offerings that you prepare, do for each one according to their number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every native born person is to do these things, bringing an offering made by fire as a pleasing aroma to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, if a resident alien lives with you, or whoever else is with you throughout your generations, let him make an offering made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the Lord. Just as you do, so is he to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is to be a single standard for your community, one statute for you and the resident alien who lives with you, a long lasting statute throughout your generations. Just as you do, so is the resident alien to do in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is to be one law and one ordinance for you and for the resident alien who lives with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Moses:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the Israelis that when they enter the land that I’m about to bring you to,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when you have eaten some of the bread that the land produces, you are to offer a raised offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to offer a cake made from the first of your bread dough as a raised offering to the Lord. Offer it as a raised offering right off your threshing floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From then on, throughout your generations give the first of your bread dough to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here’s what you are to do when you all go astray and fail to observe all these commands that the Lord had spoken to Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: including anything that the Lord commanded you by the authority of Moses, starting from the day the Lord commanded Moses and continuing through your generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When anything is done without the knowledge of the congregation, the entire community is to offer one young bull for a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the Lord, along with its meal and drink offerings offered according to procedure, and one male goat for a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priest is to make atonement for the entire community of the Israelis, and they will be forgiven for inadvertent sins. They are to bring their offering, an offering made by fire to the Lord, as well as their sin offering, into the Lord’s presence on account of their error.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the entire community of Israel will be forgiven, along with the resident alien who lives among them, since all the people will have sinned inadvertently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now when one person sins inadvertently, then he is to bring a one year old female goat for a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, in the Lord’s presence, the priest is to make atonement for the person who sinned inadvertently, that is, to make atonement on his behalf so he may be forgiven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to have a single law for the one who does things inadvertently, whether for the native-born Israeli or for the resident alien who lives among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But if some person acts with a high hand, whether a native-born or a resident alien, he blasphemes God, and that person is to be eliminated from among his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because he has despised the law of the Lord and has broken his commands, that person is certainly to be eliminated. His iniquity will remain on him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As it was when the Israelis were in the wilderness, they found a man who was gathering wood on the Sabbath day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ones who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses, Aaron, and all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they confined him until it could be declared what should be done to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses, “The man is certainly to die. The entire community is to stone him to death outside the camp.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the whole community brought him outside the camp and stoned him with stones so that he died, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the Lord instructed Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the Israelis that they are to make tassels at the edges of their garments throughout their generations and that they are to put a violet cord on the tassels at the edges of their garments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That way, when you see the tassel, you’ll remember all the commands of the Lord and you’ll observe them. Then you won’t seek your own interests and desires that lead you to be unfaithful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, remember to observe all my commands and to be holy in the presence of your God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Izhar’s son Korah, the grandson of Kohath, a descendant of Levi, along with Eliab’s sons Dathan and Abiram, and Peleth’s son On, a descendant of Reuben, took charge
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: of a rebellion against Moses, along with 250 community leaders, Israelis who were famous men and representatives from the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gathered together against Moses and Aaron and told them, “You have appropriated too much for yourselves from the entire congregation, since all of them are holy, and the Lord is among them, too. Why do you exalt yourselves over the Lord’s assembly?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses heard this, he fell on his face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he addressed Korah and his entire company, “In the morning, may the Lord reveal who belongs to him and who is holy. May he cause that person to approach him. May he cause to approach him the one whom he has chosen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Korah, you and your entire company are to bring censers
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and put fire and incense in them in the Lord’s presence tomorrow. It will be that the man whom the Lord chooses will be holy. You’re taking too much for yourselves, you descendants of Levi.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses also told Korah, “Listen now, you descendants of Levi!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is it such an insignificant thing to you that the God of Israel has separated you from the Israelis to draw you to himself, appointing you to do the work of the tent of the Lord and to stand before the community to minister to them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought you near, along with all of your relatives, the descendants of Levi. Are you also seeking the priesthood?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore you and your group have conspired against the Lord and Aaron. What is it that causes you to complain against him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses sent for Eliab’s sons Dathan and Abiram, but they responded, “We’re not coming.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is it such an insignificant thing that you brought us out of a land flowing with milk and honey, to kill us in the wilderness? Now you’re trying to make yourself be a prince and rule over us, aren’t you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You still haven’t brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey, nor have you given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Do you really think that you can make these men look the other way? We won’t go up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses was very angry, so he told the Lord, “Please don’t accept their offering. I haven’t taken even one donkey from them nor have I hurt even one of them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told Korah, “You and your entire company are to present yourselves in the Lord’s presence tomorrow—you, they, and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each man is to take a censer, put incense on it, and bring it into the Lord’s presence, each man with his censer, for a total of 250 censers. You and Aaron are each to bring his own censer.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So each man took his censer, put fire coals inside of it, placed incense in it, and then stood at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, accompanied by Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Korah had assembled the entire community in opposition to Moses and Aaron at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, the glory of the Lord appeared to the entire community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Separate yourselves from among this community, and I’ll destroy them in a moment.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they fell on their faces and said, “God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, will you be angry at the entire congregation on account of one man’s sin?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the community to move away from where Korah, Dathan, and Abiram are living.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram, and the elders of Israel followed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told the community, “Move away from the camps of these wicked men and don’t touch anything that belongs to them. That way you won’t be destroyed along with all their sins.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they all moved away from the entire area where Korah, Dathan, and Abiram were living.
Now Korah, Dathan, and Abiram stood at the entrance to their tents with their wives, sons, and little children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said, “This is how you’ll know that the Lord has sent me to do all these awesome works—they’re not coming merely from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If these people die a death similar to all other human beings, or if they are punished with a punishment common to other men, then the Lord didn’t send me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the Lord creates something new, so that the ground opens its mouth and swallows them and everything that belongs to them and they all descend directly to Sheol while still alive, then you’ll know that these men have spurned the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as he finished saying all these things, the ground under them split open.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them, all their households, everyone who was affiliated with Korah, and all of their property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they and all that belonged to them descended alive to Sheol. Then the earth closed over them. That’s how they were annihilated from the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of the Israelis who were around them ran away when they heard them crying, “…so the ground won’t swallow us up, too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, fire came from the Lord and incinerated the 250 men who offered the incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell Aaron’s son Eleazar the priest to take out the censers out of the flames and scatter the coals far away, since they are holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the censers of those rebels who died, fasten them into beaten plates to line the altar. Since they brought them into the Lord’s presence, they’re holy. They are to become a reminder to the Israelis.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers that had been burned and beat them into metal plates for the altar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to serve as a memorial to the Israelis, a reminder that no unauthorized person, who isn’t a descendant of Aaron, is to attempt to burn incense in the Lord’s presence, so that he may not become like Korah and his group, just as the Lord had spoken by the authority of Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, the very next day, the whole congregation of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron, “You’ve killed the Lord’s people!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the community gathered together against Moses and Aaron, they turned toward the Tent of Meeting. All of a sudden, a cloud covered it and the glory of the Lord appeared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron entered the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Leave this community, so I can annihilate them in a moment.”
But they fell upon their faces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses told Aaron. “Take the censer, put fire on it from the altar, and burn some incense. Then walk quickly to the congregation and atone for them, because wrath has already come out from the Lord—the plague has begun.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Aaron took the censer, just as Moses had spoken, and ran out to the center of the assembly, where a plague had begun among the people. He set the incense on fire and atoned for the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stood between the dead and the living and restrained the plague.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who died due to the plague numbered 14,700, not counting those who died due to the matter with Korah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting after the slaughter had been restrained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord instructed Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the Israelis to take a rod—one from each ancestral house, that is, one from every leader, for a total of twelve rods. Write each tribal name on his rod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are also to write Aaron’s name on the tribe of Levi, since there is to be one rod for every leader of their ancestral tribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then lay them there in the Tent of Meeting in front of the Ark of the Covenant where I’ll meet with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rod that belongs to the man whom I’ll choose will burst into bloom. That’s how I’ll put a stop to the complaints of the Israelis, who are complaining against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses spoke to the Israelis, and each of the tribe leaders gave him a rod, one for each leader, according to their ancestral tribes, for a total of twelve rods. Aaron’s rod was one of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses laid out the rods in the Lord’s presence, inside the Tent of Testimony.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning, Moses went to the Tent of Testimony and the rod of Aaron of the tribe of Levi had burst into bloom! It sprouted buds, bloomed blossoms, and produced fully ripe almonds!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses took out all the rods from the Lord’s presence to show all the Israelis. Everybody looked, and then each man took his rod.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Moses, “Return Aaron’s rod before the testimony to be kept for a reminder against the rebels so that you may put an end to their complaints against me and so that they won’t die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses did exactly what the Lord had commanded him to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Israelis told Moses, “We’re sure to die! We’re all going to perish—all of us!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who comes near or approaches the Lord’s tent is to die. Are all of us going to die?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the Lord told Aaron, “You, your sons, and your father’s tribe with you are to bear the iniquity of the sanctuary. Also, you and your sons with you are to bear the iniquity of your priesthood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moreover, bring your brothers from your father’s tribe of Levi with you, so they may join you and minister to you while you and your sons with you stand in the presence of the Tent of Testimony.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to take care of your concerns and all the responsibilities involved with the tent. But they’re not to approach the holy vessels or the altar. That way, neither you nor they will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to join you to maintain services related to the Tent of Meeting, for all the responsibilities involved with the tent. But no unauthorized person is to approach you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take care of the sanctuary and the services of the altar so that there won’t be any more wrath on the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Notice that I’ve taken your brothers, the descendants of Levi, from among the Israelis, giving them to you as a gift from the Lord to perform the service of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you and your sons with you are to maintain your priestly duties and all matters that concern the altar and what is housed within the veil. You are to perform these services. I’m giving you the priesthood as a gift of service, but any unauthorized person who approaches is to be put to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Aaron, “Look! I am indeed placing you in charge of my raised offerings and the holy things concerning the Israelis. Because of your anointing, I’m giving you and your sons a prescribed portion forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what is to belong to you from consecrated offerings spared from the fire: all of their offerings, grain offerings, sin offerings, and trespass offerings that they render to me. They’re to be considered most sacred to you and your sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may eat them as consecrated gifts. Every male may eat them. They’re sacred for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The raised offering and wave offerings presented by the Israelis are yours, too. I’ve given them to you, to your sons, and to your daughters as a prescribed apportionment forever. Everyone who is clean in your household may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the best oil, wine, grain, and first fruits that they give to the Lord are to belong to you. Everyone who is clean in your household may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The first ripe fruits of everything that the land produces and that they bring to the Lord are yours, too. Everyone who is clean in your household may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every devoted thing in Israel is yours, too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything that opens the womb, any living thing that they bring to the Lord—whether from human beings or animals—are for you. Just be sure that you redeem the firstborn of people and the firstborn of unclean animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those that can be redeemed, you are to redeem at the age of one month, based on your estimate—for five shekels of silver, according to the shekel of the sanctuary, that is, for 20 gerahs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you are not to redeem the firstborn of a cow, sheep, or a female goat. They are holy. You are to sprinkle their blood on the altar and burn their fat for an offering made by fire, a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their meat is to belong to you, just as the breast wave offering and the right thigh is yours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m giving you, your sons, and your daughters as a prescribed portion forever all the raised offerings of the consecrated things that the Israelis offer to the Lord. It’s a salt covenant forever before the Lord with you and your descendants with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Aaron, “You are not to have any inheritance in the land, nor are you to have any portion among the people. I am your portion and your inheritance among the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As to the descendants of Levi, certainly I’ve given all the tithes in Israel as their inheritance in return for their services that they perform at the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, the Israelis need no longer come to the Tent of Meeting, so they won’t suffer the consequences of their sin and die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Levi are to perform the service of the Tent of Meeting and they are to bear their iniquity. This is to be a statute forever, throughout your generations, that they are not to receive an inheritance among the Israelis,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because I’ve given to the descendants of Levi the tithes that the Israelis bring to the Lord as raised offering. Therefore I told them that, unlike the Israelis, they won’t receive an inheritance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the descendants of Levi that when they receive tithes from the Israelis (the tithes that I’ve given you from them as an inheritance), you are to offer a tenth of it as a raised offering for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your raised offerings are to be accounted for you as though it were grain from threshing floors and full produce from wine vats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to offer a raised offering to the Lord from all your tithes that you receive from the Israelis. Give Aaron the priest the raised offering of the Lord
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: out of all the most consecrated offerings that you receive, that is, all the raised offerings of the Lord, with all its best and the most holy parts of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell them that when they bring the best from it, as far as the descendants of Levi are concerned, it is to be considered like produce from the threshing floors and wine vats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and your household may eat it anywhere, because it’s a reward to you in return for your services at the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You won’t sin by offering the best of it, and you are not to profane the sacred things of the Israelis, so that you won’t die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses and Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is the ordinance of the law that the Lord commanded that the Israelis be told: They are to bring you a spotless red heifer, without physical defect, that has never been fitted with a yoke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to deliver it to Eleazar the priest, and it is to be brought outside the camp and slaughtered in his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eleazar the priest is to take blood from it with his finger and sprinkle the blood in front of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire heifer is to be incinerated in his presence, including its skin, its flesh, its blood, and its dung.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priest is to take some cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet material and throw it into the middle of the burning heifer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest is to wash his clothes and bathe himself with water, after which he may enter the camp, but he is to remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever takes part in the burning is to wash his clothes and bathe himself in water and is to remain unclean until the evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then someone who is clean is to gather the ashes of the heifer and lay them outside the camp in a clean place. This is to be done for the community of Israel to use for water of purification from sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever gathers the ashes of the heifer is to wash his clothes and is to remain unclean until the evening. This ordinance is to remain for the benefit of both the Israelis and the resident aliens who live among them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Whoever comes in contact with the body of a dead person is to remain unclean for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is to purify himself on the third day and he will be clean on the seventh day. But if he can’t purify himself on the third day then he can’t be clean on the seventh day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who comes in contact with a dead person (that is, with the corpse of a human being who has died), but who does not purify himself, defiles the Lord’s tent. That person is to be eliminated from Israel, because the water of impurity wasn’t sprinkled on him. He remains unclean and his uncleanness will remain with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is the procedure to follow when a man dies in his tent: Everyone who enters the tent and everyone in it is to remain unclean for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every open vessel that has no covering fastened around it is to be considered unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever is out in an open field and touches the body of someone who was killed by a sword, or a dead body, or someone’s bones, or a grave, he is to be considered unclean for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now as for the unclean, they are to take ashes from the burning sin offering, and pour running water on it inside a vessel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A clean person is to take some hyssop, dip it in water, and then sprinkle it on the tent, on every vessel, and on whoever was there (that is, on whoever touched the bones, the killed person, or the dead body, including whoever dug the grave).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The clean person is to sprinkle the unclean person on the third day and seventh day and then he is to purify himself on the seventh day, wash his clothes, and bathe with water. He is to be considered clean at evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The person who is unclean but who doesn’t purify himself is to be eliminated from contact with the assembly, since he has defiled the Lord’s sanctuary and the water of impurity wasn’t sprinkled on him. He is to be considered unclean
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as a continuing reminder to them. Whoever sprinkles the water of impurity is to wash his clothes, and whoever comes in contact with the water of impurity is to remain unclean until evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, anything that the unclean person touches is to be considered unclean and the person who touches him is to be considered unclean until the evening.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire community of the Israelis entered the Zin wilderness during the first month. The people stayed in Kadesh. Miriam died and was buried there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there was no water for the community, so they gathered together against Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the people argued with Moses, they told him, “We wish that we had died when our relatives died in the Lord’s presence!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you bring the assembly of the Lord into this wilderness? So we and our cattle could die here?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you take us out of Egypt and bring us to this terrible place? There’s no place to plant seeds, fig trees, vines, or pomegranates! And there’s no water to drink!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went into the presence of the community at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting and fell on their faces. Then the glory of the Lord appeared to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take the rod, gather the community together, and then you and your brother Aaron are to speak to the rock right before their eyes. It will release water. As you bring water to them from the rock, the community and the cattle will be able to drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses took the rod in the Lord’s presence, just as he had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron gathered the community together in front of the rock. “Pay attention, you rebels!” Moses told them. “Are we to bring you water from this rock?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses raised his hand and struck the rock twice with his rod. Lots of water gushed out, and both the community and their cattle were able to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord rebuked Moses and Aaron, telling Moses: “Because you both didn’t believe me, because you didn’t consecrate me as holy in the presence of the Israelis, you won’t be the ones to bring this congregation into the land that I’m about to give them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the Israelis argued with the Lord and he was set apart among them, this place was called the Meribah Springs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom with this message: “This is what your relative Israel says: ‘You know all the hardships we’ve encountered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our ancestors went down to Egypt, where we lived for many years. But the Egyptians treated us and our ancestors viciously.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we cried to the Lord and he heard our voice, sending us a messenger who brought us out of Egypt. Now look! We’ve arrived in Kadesh, a city at the extreme end of your territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Permit us now to pass through your land. We won’t pass through your fields or vineyards, and we won’t drink water from your wells. We’ll keep to the King’s Highway without turning either right or left until we have passed through your territory.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Edom replied, “You are not to pass through my land. If you do, I’ll come out and start a war with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Israelis replied, “Permit us to travel on the highway. If we and our cattle drink your water, we’ll pay the price you ask. Only please let us walk through, and nothing more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But still he replied, “No. You’re not to pass through.” Then Edom went out to meet Moses with a vast army and a lot of military might.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s how Edom refused Israel passage through their territory. So Israel turned away from there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They traveled from Kadesh, and then the entire community of the Israelis arrived at Mount Hor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor, near the territory of Edom,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Aaron is to be gathered to his people, since he is not to enter the land that I’m about to give the Israelis. After all, you both rebelled against my command at the Meribah Springs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So take Aaron and his son Eleazar and ascend Mount Hor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remove Aaron’s vestments and place them on his son Eleazar, because Aaron is to be gathered to his people and die there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses did just what the Lord had commanded. They ascended Mount Hor right in front of the entire community.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Moses was stripping Aaron’s garments from him and clothing Aaron’s son Eleazar with them, Aaron died there on top of the mountain. Afterwards, Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the entire community saw that Aaron had died, they mourned in memory of Aaron for 30 days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming along the Atharim caravan route, he fought against Israel and took some of them captive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Israel made this vow in the Lord’s presence: “If you give these people into our control, we intend to devote their cities to total destruction.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord heard what Israel had decided to do, he delivered the Canaanites to them, and Israel exterminated them and their cities. They named the place Hormah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, they traveled from Mount Hor along the caravan route by way of the Sea of Reeds and went around the land of Edom. But when the people got impatient because it was a long route,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the people complained against the Lord and Moses. “Why did you bring us out of Egypt to die in the wilderness?” they asked. “There’s no food and water, and we’re tired of this worthless bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In response, the Lord sent poisonous serpents among the people to bite them. As a result, many people of Israel died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people approached Moses and admitted, “We’ve sinned by speaking against the Lord and you. Pray to the Lord, that he’ll remove the serpents from us.” So Moses prayed in behalf of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord instructed Moses, “Make a poisonous serpent out of brass and fasten it to a pole. Anyone who has been bitten and who looks at it will live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses made a bronze serpent and fastened it to a pole. If a person who had been bitten by a poisonous serpent looked to the serpent, he lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, the Israelis traveled and encamped at Oboth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they traveled from Oboth and encamped at Iye-abarim, in the wilderness that is in the vicinity of Moab’s eastern border.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there, they traveled and encamped in the valley of Zered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they traveled to the other side of Arnon and camped in the wilderness that borders the territory of the Amorites. (Arnon borders Moab between Moab and the Amorites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: which is why the Book of the Wars of the Lord reads, “Waheb and Suphah and the wadis of the Arnon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the slope of the valleys, that extends to the dwelling places of Ar and the borders of Moab.”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there they traveled to the Well of Beer, where the Lord had instructed Moses, “Gather the people together and I’ll give you water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That’s also where Israel sang this song:
Rise up, well!
    Sing to it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It’s the well that the leaders dug,
    the one carved out by the nobles of the people
        with their scepters and staffs.
Then they moved on in the wilderness from there to Mattanah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then from Mattanah to Nahaliel, from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and from Bamoth to the valley of Moab where their fields are, and from there to the top of Mount Pisgah, that looks down toward the open desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, Israel sent messengers to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who conveyed this request:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Permit us to pass through your land. We won’t trespass in your fields or vineyards. We won’t drink water from any well, and we’ll only travel along the King’s Highway until we’ve passed through your territory.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead of letting Israel pass through his territory, Sihon mustered his entire army and marched out to meet them in the wilderness. He arrived at Jahaz and attacked Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Israel defeated him in battle and took possession of all his lands from Arnon to Jabbok, including the Ammonites, even though the border of the Ammonites was strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel captured all of those cities, occupied all the Amorite cities in Heshbon, and all its towns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Heshbon was the capital city of Sihon, king of the Amorites, who fought against the previous king of Moab and captured all his land from his capital city to Arnon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore the ones who speak in proverbs say:
Come to Heshbon
    and let it be built!
        Let the city of Sihon be established!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A fire has gone out from Heshbon,
    and a flame from the city of Sihon.
It consumed Ar of Moab
    and the lords of the high places who lived in Arnon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to you, Moab!
    You are destroyed, you people of Chemosh!
He has given up his sons as fugitives
    and his daughters have gone into captivity
        to Sihon, king of the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We’ve fired at them.
    Heshbon has perished as far as Dibon.
We’ve destroyed them as far as Nophah
    even as far as Medeba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel lived in Amorite territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses sent out explorers to scout Jazer. They captured its towns and drove out the Amorites who were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they turned toward Bashan. However, Og, the king of Bashan, mustered his army and went out to attack them at Edrei.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses, “You are not to fear him, because I’m going to deliver him, his entire army, and his land into your control. Do to him just what you’ve done to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who used to live in Heshbon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they attacked him, his sons, and his entire army, until there wasn’t even a single survivor left. Then they took possession of his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelis continued their travels, eventually encamping on the plains of Moab beside the Jordan River opposite Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zippor’s son Balak saw everything that Israel had done to the Amorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result, Moab greatly feared the people, because they were so numerous. Because a sense of impending doom was afflicting the Moabites as they faced the Israelis,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the Moabites told the elders of Midian, “This horde of people is about to lick up everything around us, like an ox licks up the green ground.”
At that time, Zippor’s son Balak was the king of Moab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent messengers to Beor’s son Balaam in Pethor, near the Euphrates River, the land where the descendants of his people originated, to summon his aid. He said, “Look! A group of people have escaped from Egypt. They cover the surface of the whole earth, and are sitting here right in front of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So come right now and curse this people for me, because there are too many of them for me to handle. Perhaps I’ll be able to strike them down and drive them out of the land, since I know that whomever you bless is blessed and whomever you curse is cursed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the elders of Moab and Midian left to visit Balaam, bringing an honorarium with them, and communicated Balak’s concerns to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In answer, Balaam told them, “Stay here for the night and I’ll bring back a message to you, depending on what the Lord says to me.” So the officers of Moab stayed with Balaam overnight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God visited Balaam and asked him, “Who are these men with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam told God, “Zippor’s son Balak, king of Moab, sent them to me and said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Look! A group of people have escaped from Egypt. They cover the surface of the whole earth! So come right now and curse them for me. Perhaps I’ll be able to fight against them and drive them out.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God told Balaam, “Don’t go with them. Don’t curse the people, because they’re blessed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balaam got up the next morning and told Balak’s officials, “Go back to your homeland, because the Lord has refused me permission to go with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak’s officials got up, returned to Balak and reported, “Balaam refused to come with us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In response, Balak sent more officers—higher ranking ones, at that!—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who approached Balaam with this message: “This is what Zippor’s son Balak says: ‘Don’t let anything get in the way of your coming to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m determined to reward you generously, and I’ll do everything you tell me to do. So come right away and curse this people for me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam responded to Balak’s entourage by saying, “Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I won’t double-cross the command of the Lord my God in even the slightest way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, stay here overnight so I may learn what the Lord might say to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God came to visit Balaam that same night and told him, “If the men come to call on you, get up and go with them, but be sure to do only what I tell you to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next morning, Balaam got up, saddled his donkey, and started to leave, accompanied by the Moabite officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At this, the anger of the Lord flared up against Balaam, because he was leaving. So the angel of the Lord stood in the way to oppose him. As Balaam was riding his donkey, accompanied by two of his servants,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all of a sudden the donkey saw the angel of the Lord standing in the way, with an unsheathed sword in his hand! The donkey turned off the road and went into an open field. Balaam started beating the donkey in order to turn her back to the road,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the angel of the Lord stood on a narrow path that crossed the vineyards. It had walls on both sides of the path.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, she squeezed herself so close to the wall that Balaam’s foot was pressed to the wall. So he beat her again!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord went along a little further and stood in a much narrower space, where it was impossible to turn either right or left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, she crouched down under Balaam. As a result, Balaam got so angry that he started to whip the donkey with his staff.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That’s when the Lord enabled the donkey to speak. She asked Balaam, “What did I do to you that you would beat me in the space of only three footsteps?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Because you’re playing a dirty trick on me,” Balaam answered the donkey. “If only I had a sword in my hand! I’d kill you right now!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But in response, the donkey asked Balaam, “I’m your donkey that you’ve ridden on in the past without incident, am I not, and I’m the same donkey you’re riding on right now, am I not? Am I in the habit of treating you like this?”
“No,” he admitted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord enabled Balaam to see, so he observed the angel of the Lord standing in the way, with an unsheathed sword in his hand. So he bowed down and prostrated himself on his face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord asked him, “Why did you beat your donkey in the space of only three footsteps? I’ve come to oppose you, because I say that what you’re doing is perverted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The donkey saw me and turned in front of me in the space of those three footsteps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If she hadn’t turned away from me, I would have killed you by now and left her alive!”
At this, Balaam replied to the angel of the Lord, “I’ve sinned! I didn’t know that you were standing to meet me on the road. So now, since it displeases you, let me go back.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the angel of the Lord told Balaam, “Go with the men, but deliver only the message that I’m going to give you.” So Balaam went with Balak’s officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Balak heard that Balaam had arrived, he went out to meet him in the city of Moab on the border of Arnon at the extreme end of his territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balak asked Balaam, “Didn’t I repeatedly send for you to summon you? Why didn’t you come to me? I can pay you well, can’t I?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam answered Balak, “Well, I’m here now. I’ve come to you, but I can’t just say anything, can I? I’ll speak only what God puts in my mouth to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So accompanied by Balaam and Balak’s officials, Balak traveled to Kiriath-huzoth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where he sacrificed oxen and sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day, Balak brought Balaam up to Bamoth-baal, where he could see part of the community of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam told Balak, “Build for me here seven altars and prepare here for me seven bulls and seven rams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak did just as Balaam instructed. Balak and Balaam offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Balaam instructed Balak, “Stand by your offering and leave me alone by myself. Perhaps the Lord will come to meet me. I’ll tell you whatever he reveals to me.”
And so he went to a high place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: where the Lord met with Balaam, who told him, “I’ve prepared seven altars and offered bulls and rams on an altar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord gave Balaam this message. “Return to Balak and speak to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balaam returned to where Balak had been standing, that is, next to his offerings, accompanied by all the Moabite officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Balaam uttered this prophetic statement:
“King Balak of Moab brought me from Aram,
    from the eastern mountains,
        and told me,
‘Come and curse Jacob for me.
    Come and curse Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But how can I curse those whom God hasn’t cursed?
    How can I denounce
        those whom the Lord hasn’t denounced?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I saw them from the top of the rocks.
    I watched them from the hills.
Truly this is a people that lives by itself
    and doesn’t matter among the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can count the dust of Jacob?
    Who can number the dust of Israel?
Let me die the death of the righteous,
    and may I end up like him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What are you doing to me?” Balak asked Balaam. “I brought you to curse my enemies, not pronounce a blessing!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in response, Balaam asked, “Shouldn’t I be careful to communicate only what the Lord puts in my mouth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come with me to another place where you can see them,” Balak replied. “You’ll only see a portion of them, because you won’t be able to see them completely. Come and curse them from there for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak took him to the field of Zophim, and from there to the top of Mount Pisgah, where he built seven altars and then offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told Balak, “Stand by your offering while I go alone to meet the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord met with Balaam and gave a message to him. “Now go back to Balak and speak to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Balaam returned to where Balak had been standing, that is, next to his offerings, accompanied by the Moabite officials.
“What did the Lord say?” Balak asked him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In response, Balaam uttered this prophetic statement:
“Stand up, Balak, and pay attention!
    Listen to me, you son of Zippor!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God is not a human male—
    he doesn’t lie,
nor is he a human being—
    he never vacillates.
Once he speaks up,
    he’s going to act, isn’t he?
Once he makes a promise,
    he’ll fulfill it, won’t he?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! I’ve received a blessing,
    and so I will bless.
        I won’t withdraw it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has not responded to iniquity in Jacob
    or gazed at mischief in Israel.
The Lord his God is with them,
    and the triumphant cry of a king is among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From Egypt God brought them—
    his strength was like a wild ox!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No Satanic plan against Jacob
    nor divination against Israel
        can ever prevail.
When the time is right,
    it is to be asked about Jacob and Israel,
        ‘What has God accomplished?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! The people are like lions.
    Like the lion, he rises up!
He does not lie down again
    until he has consumed his prey
        and drunk the blood of the slain.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balak told Balaam, “Don’t curse them or bless them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Didn’t I tell you,” Balaam responded to Balak, “that I’ll say whatever the Lord tells me to say?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak exhorted Balaam, “Let’s go right now! I’ll take you to another place. Maybe God will agree to have you curse them for me from there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Mount Peor, which overlooks the open wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balaam told Balak, “Build seven altars for me right here. Then prepare seven bulls and seven rams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balak did just what Balaam had instructed—he offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Balaam noticed that the Lord was pleased that Balaam was blessing Israel, he didn’t behave as he had time after time before, that is, to practice divination. Instead, he turned with his face to the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: looked up, and saw Israel encamped in their respective tribal order. Just then, the spirit of God came upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Balaam uttered this prophetic statement:
“A declaration by Beor’s son Balaam,
    a declaration by the strong, blind man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A declaration from one who hears what God has to say,
    who saw the vision that the Almighty revealed,
who keeps stumbling
    with open eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jacob, your tents are so fine,
    as well as your dwelling places, O Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They’re spread out like valleys,
    like gardens along river banks,
like aloe planted by the Lord,
    or like cedars beside water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will pour water from his buckets,
    and his descendants will stream forth like abundant water.
His king will be more exalted than Agag
    when he exalts his own kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God is bringing them out of Egypt
    with the strength of an ox.
He’ll devour enemy nations,
    break their bones,
        and impale them with arrows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He crouches, laying low like a lion.
    Who would awaken him?
Those who bless you are blessed,
    and those who curse you are cursed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Balak flew into a rage and he started hitting his fists together. “I called you to curse my enemies,” he yelled at Balaam. “But look here! You’ve blessed them three times!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now get out of here! I had promised you that I would definitely honor you, but now the Lord has kept me from doing that!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Balaam replied to Balak, “I told your messengers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Even if Balak gives me his palace full of silver and gold, I won’t double-cross the command of the Lord and do anything—whether good or evil—on my own initiative, because I’m going to say whatever the Lord says.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, since I have to return to my people, come and listen while I tell you what this people will be doing to your people in the last days.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Balaam uttered this prophetic statement:
“The declaration by Beor’s son Balaam,
    a declaration by the strong, blind man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A declaration from one who hears what God has to say,
    who knows what the Most High knows,
who saw the vision that the Almighty revealed,
    who keeps stumbling with open eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I can see him,
    but not right now.
I observe him,
    but from a distance. 
A star streams forth from Jacob;
    a scepter arises from Israel.
He will crush Moab’s forehead,
    along with all of Seth’s descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Edom will be a conquered nation
    and Seir will be Israel’s defeated foe,
        while Israel performs valiantly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will rule over Jacob,
    annihilating those who survive in the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next, Balaam looked directly at Amalek and then uttered this prophetic statement:
“Even though Amalek is an international leader,
    his future is permanent destruction.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Balaam also uttered this prophetic statement about the Kenites:
“Your dwelling places are stable,
    because your nest is carved in solid rock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, Kain will be incinerated.
    How long will it take until Asshur takes you hostage?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Finally, he uttered this prophetic statement:
“Ah, who can live,
    unless God makes it happen?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ships under control of Kittim will devastate Asshur and Eber,
    until they are permanently destroyed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Balaam got up, returned to his country, and Balak went on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Israel remained encamped in Shittim, the people began to commit sexual immorality with Moabite women,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who also invited the people to the sacrifices of their gods. So the people ate what they had sacrificed and then worshipped their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people joined the Baal-peor cult. As a result, the anger of the Lord flared up against Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so the Lord told Moses, “Take all the leaders of the people and execute them in broad daylight for the Lord, so the Lord’s burning anger may be withdrawn from Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses ordered the judges of Israel, “Each one of you is to execute the men in his own tribe who joined the Baal-peor cult.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That very moment, one of the Israelis arrived, bringing to his brothers one of the Midianite women, right in front of Moses and the entire community of Israel, while they were weeping at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Eleazar’s son Phinehas, grandson of Aaron the priest saw this, he jumped up from the middle of the community, grabbed a javelin in his hand,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: followed the Israeli man inside his tent, and impaled the two of them—the Israeli man and the woman—right through both of them and into her abdomen. Then the plague infecting the Israelis was brought to a halt. Nevertheless,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 24,000 people died because of the plague.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Eleazar’s son Phinehas, grandson of Aaron the priest, has turned my wrath away from Israel. Because his zealousness reflected my own zeal for them, I didn’t consume Israel in my jealousy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, I’m certainly going to be giving him my covenant of peace,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for him and for his descendants after him, too, a covenant of perpetual priesthood, because he was zealous for his God and made atonement for the Israelis.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the name of the Israeli man who was slain, along with the Midianite woman, was Salu’s son Zimri, a leader from the tribe of Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman who was slain, that is, the Midianite woman, was named Cozbi. She was the daughter of Zur, a leader of one of the ancestral houses of Midian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, the Lord ordered Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Attack the Midianites and execute them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they’ve acted deceitfully, bringing trouble to you in this incident at Peor with Cozbi, daughter of a prince from Midian, who was killed during the plague that came about because of the incident at Peor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the plague was over, the Lord told Moses and Aaron the priest’s son Eleazar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take a census of the entire community of Israel from the age of 20 years and above, according to each ancestral tribe, counting everyone who is able to go out to war in Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke to them in the plains of Moab, by the Jordan River in Jericho.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They counted every male Israeli who had come out of Egypt and who was 20 years old and above, just as the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Reuben, Israel’s firstborn, the descendants of Reuben included from Hanoch, the family of the descendants of Hanoch; from Pallu, the family of the descendants of Pallu;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Hezron, the family of the descendants of Hezron; and from Carmi, the family of the descendants of Carmi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of the descendants of Reuben numbered 43,730.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Pallu’s son was Eliab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Eliab were Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. Dathan and Abiram were removed from the community because they joined the rebellion against Moses and Aaron, as did Korah’s company when they rebelled against the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ground had opened its mouth and swallowed them up, along with Korah. Also, that group died when the fire devoured 250 men as a warning sign,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Korah’s direct descendants didn’t die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Simeon, listed according to their families, included: From Nemuel, the family of the descendants of Nemuel; from Jamin, the family of the descendants of Jamin; from Jachin, the family of the descendants of Jachin;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Zerah, the family of the descendants of Zerah; and from Shaul, the family of the descendants of Shaul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of the descendants of Simeon numbered 22,200.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Gad, listed according to their families, included: From Zephon, the family of the descendants of Zephon; from Haggi, the family of the descendants of Haggi; from Shuni, the family of the descendants of Shuni;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Ozni, the family of the descendants of Ozni; from Eri, the family of the descendants of Eri;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Arod, the family of the descendants of Arod; and from Areli, the family of the descendants of Areli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of the descendants of Gad numbered 40,500.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Judah originally included Er and Onan, though Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Judah, listed according to their families, included: From Shelah, the family of the descendants of Shelah; from Perez, the family of the descendants of Perez; and from Zerah, the family of the descendants of Zerah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Perez included: From Hezron, the family of the descendants of Hezron; and from Hamul, the family of the descendants of Hamul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of Judah numbered 76,500.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Issachar, listed according to their families, included: From Tola, the family of the descendants of Tola; from Puvah, the family of the descendants of Puvah;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Jashub, the family of the descendants of Jashub; and from Shimron, the family of the descendants of Shimron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of Issachar numbered 64,300.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Zebulun, listed according to their families, included: From Sered, the family of the descendants of Sered; from Elon, the family of the descendants of Elon; and from Jahleel, the family of the descendants of Jahleel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of the descendants of Zebulun numbered 60,500.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Joseph, listed according to their families, included Manasseh and Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Manasseh included: From Machir, the family of the descendants of Machir. (Machir was the father of Gilead.) From Gilead, the family of the Gileadites
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: included: From Iezer, the family of the descendants of Iezer; from Helek, the family of the descendants of Helek;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Asriel, the family of the descendants of Asriel; from Shechem, the family of the descendants of Shechem;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Shemida, the family of the descendants of Shemida; and from Hepher, the family of the descendants of Hepher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hepher’s son Zelophehad had no sons, but the names of Zelophehad’s daughters were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of Manasseh numbered 52,700.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Ephraim, listed according to their families, included: From Shuthelah, the family of the descendants of Shuthelah; from Becher, the family of the descendants of Becher; and from Tahan, the family of the descendants of Tahan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Shuthelah included from Eran, the family of the descendants of Eran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of Ephraim numbered 32,500. These were the descendants of Joseph, listed according to their families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Benjamin, listed according to their families, included: From Bela, the family of the descendants of Bela; from Ashbel, the family of the descendants of Ashbel; from Ahiram, the family of the descendants of Ahiram;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Shephupham, the family of the descendants of Shephupham; and from Hupham, the family of the descendants of Hupham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Bela were Ard and Naaman: From Ard, the family of the descendants of Ard; and from Naaman, the family of the descendants of Naaman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These descendants of Benjamin’s families numbered 45,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Dan, listed according to their families, included the families of the descendants of Shuham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the families of the Shuhamites numbered 64,400.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Asher, listed according to their families, included: From Imnah, the family of the descendants of Imnah; from Ishvi, the family of the descendants of Ishvi; and from Beriah, the family of the descendants of Beriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The descendants of Beriah included: From Heber, the family of the descendants of Heber; and from Malchiel, the family of the descendants of Malchiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The name of Asher’s daughter was Serah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These descendants of Asher numbered 53,400.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tribe of Naphtali, listed according to their families, included: From Jahzeel, the family of the descendants of Jahzeel; from Guni, the family of the descendants of Guni;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Jezer, the family of the descendants of Jezer; and from Shillem, the family of the descendants of Shillem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These families of Naphtali numbered 45,400.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total of those numbered among the Israelis was 601,730.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord told Moses,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The land is to be divided for an inheritance according to the total number of these names.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The more there are in number, you are to increase their inheritance, and the less there are in number, you are to decrease their inheritance. You are to provide an inheritance to each based on the size of their family,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the land is to be divided by lot, inheriting according to the names of their ancestor’s tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Depending on the lot, the portion of their inheritance is to be divided between those with more members and those with fewer members.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who were numbered from the descendants of Levi, listed according to their families, included: From Gershon, the family of the descendants of Gershon; from Kohath, the family of the descendants of Kohath; and from Merari, the family of the descendants of Merari.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the families of Levi: The family of the descendants of Libni, the family of the descendants of Hebron, the family of the descendants of Mahli, the family of the descendants of Musha, and the family of the descendants of Korah.
Now Kohath had a son named Amram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amram’s wife was Levi’s daughter Jochebed, who was born to Levi in Egypt. She gave birth to Aaron, Moses, and their sister Miriam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Aaron were born Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Nadab and Abihu died when they offered unauthorized fire in the Lord’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of those individuals numbered 23,000. No male from the age of a month and above was numbered among the Israelis because no inheritance was to be assigned to them among the Israelis.
verses.speaker: Narrator
